Detailed Description

OBEX server which uses the BinData and DataSink interfaces for transferring data.

This class offers a more convenient interface than the ObexServer by relieving the application programmer from the tedious job of assembling and segmenting application data. It is therefore the recommended base class for both MMI applications and APOXI extensions wishing to provide server services based on OBEX.

Member Enumeration Documentation

anonymous enum
 

Buffer sizes used by the server during GET operations.

Enumerator:
MinGetFragSize  Minimum buffer size supported.
DefGetFragSize  Default buffer size.

Default constructor.

Default-constructed instances must be initialized using Init() before using them the first time.

ObexDataServer::ObexDataServer (  ExecutionContext *  ctx_ptr  ) 
 

Constructor. Constructs a usable object instance.

Intended to be used with dynamically allocated objects (new).

Parameters:
ctx_ptr Execution context to be used by the server. All notification methods (protected: On.....()) will be called from this context. You may pass '0' as actual parameter to specify the currently active context, which must be valid at construction the time.

Member Function Documentation

ObexResult ObexDataServer::AcceptData (  DataSink *  data_sink_ptr,
UINT32  max_data_size
) 
 

Accepts incoming BODY data within a PUT or GET operation.

May be called only after OnDataAvailable() was signalled to the server. Calling AcceptData() implies posting a SUCCESS response which means it does not make sense to call PostResponse() synchronously before or after AcceptData().

Parameters:
data_sink_ptr Pointer to a DataSink instance to hold the data sent by the remote client.
max_data_size Maximum amount of data (in octets) which can be written to the DataSink instance. When this limit is exceeded, data transfer is automatically cancelled by the server.
Returns:
ObexResult which evaluates to 'TRUE' when the data transfer procedure was successfully initiated, 'FALSE' otherwise.

UINT32 ObexDataServer::GetProgressInBytes (   )  const
 

Returns the cumulative progress in transferring data.

This method returns the amount of data already transferred for a pending PUT (inbound data) or GET (outbound data) operation. The final value is preserved even beyond completion of that operation, hence it is reset to '0' when a new operation is accepted.

Reimplemented from ObexServer.

ObexHeaderList & ObexDataServer::GetResponseHeaderList (   ) 
 

Provides access to the header list of the next response to be sent.

A new response header (SUCCESS response) is automatically set up when a request is accepted by the server. If an error response is needed, it can be set up by calling InitResponse(). This method can then be used to gain access to the header list of the response, which permits adding headers by calling the various AddHeader() methods provided by ObexHeaderList.

See also:
ObexHeaderList.

void ObexDataServer::Init (  ExecutionContext *  ctx_ptr  )  [virtual]
 

Initializes a default-constructed object.

Parameters:
ctx_ptr Execution context in which the server is to be run. You may pass '0' as actual parameter to specify the current execution context. In the latter case, the current context must be valid when Init() is called.

Reimplemented from ObexServer.

ObexResult ObexDataServer::InitResponse (  ObexObject::ResponseCode  resp_code  ) 
 

Manually sets up the next response to be sent.

Parameters:
resp_code OBEX response code to be used.
A new response header (SUCCESS response) is automatically set up when a request is accepted by the server. It can be overwritten by calling this method.

virtual void ObexDataServer::OnAbort (  const ObexHeaderList &  headers  )  [inline, protected, virtual]
 

Indicates the current PUT or GET operation is being aborted by the remote client.

On return from this method, an ABORT response is automatically transmitted.

Parameters:
headers Header list which may or may not contain optional ABORT headers sent by the remote client.

void ObexDataServer::OnConnect (  const ObexHeaderList &  headers,
UINT8  flags
)  [protected, virtual]
 

Indicates an incoming CONNECT request.

When a TARGET was specified as part of the server's OBEX URL it will accept only CONNECT requests with a matching TARGET header. Therefore this does not need to be checked by application SW. On entry to OnConnect, the server will build a SUCCESS response. When the server was opened specifying a TARGET, a CONNECTION ID is assigned and the pre-build response will contain the following headers: CONNECTION_ID=<set_by_server>}, TARGET=<client's WHO>, WHO=<server's TARGET>.

Please note that PostResponse() must be called in order to continue the ongoing operation.

Parameters:
headers Header list which contains the headers of the CONNECT request sent by the remote client, for example TARGET and WHO.

Reimplemented in ObexFtpDataServer.

void ObexDataServer::OnDataAvailable (   )  [protected, virtual]
 

Indicates OBEX BODY data is available.

This notification method is normally called within a PUT operation to indicate the availability of OBEX BODY data. To initiate data transfer, call AcceptData() and pass it a DataSink instance responsible for storing received data and the maximum data size to be received. When the size limit is exceeded, data transmission is automatically cancelled and an Internal Server Error is signalled to the remote client.

Reimplemented in ObexFtpDataServer.

void ObexDataServer::OnDataComplete (   )  [protected, virtual]
 

Indicates that a complete OBEX object BODY has been received.

When this method is called all incoming OBEX BODY data of the current operation has been received and written to the DataSink instance which was passed to Accept(). Now that the whole object is available to the server, it can be parsed to prepare for the decision whether it should be considered valid or not. Under normal circumstances (valid data was received) PostResponse() can be called to acknowledge data reception. In case of error, first call InitResponse() to set the error cause and optionally add response headers, then invoke PostResponse().

Calling PostResponse() will cause the final response to be sent to the remote client, informing it on the server's decision and finish the operation.

The default implementation of this method just calls PostResponse(), so if you override the method please don't call the inherited method from your own implementation !

void ObexDataServer::OnDataRequested (   )  [protected, virtual]
 

Indicates OBEX BODY data can be sent now.

This notification method is called within a GET operation to indicate the end of the request phase. In other words, all headers specifying the object to be retrieved have been sent and the server is now waiting for response headers and data. OBEX Headers required to describe the properties of the returned object should be added now. These could include for example TYPE, NAME and LENGTH headers. Then automatic data transmission can be launched by calling ProvideData() and passing it an instance of BinData responsible for providing the object content.

Reimplemented in ObexFtpDataServer.

void ObexDataServer::OnDelete (   )  [protected, virtual]
 

Indicates the current PUT operation is a PUT DELETE.

This notificatiom method indicates that the current PUT operation does not contain any BODY headers and therefore represents a PUT DELETE.

Reimplemented in ObexFtpDataServer.

virtual void ObexDataServer::OnDisconnect (  const ObexHeaderList &  headers  )  [inline, protected, virtual]
 

Indicates an incoming DISCONNECT request.

This method is invoked when an OBEX DISCONNECT request was received. On entry to OnDisconnect, the server will build a SUCCESS response. Since the OBEX specification forbids rejecting a DISCONNECT request for other reasons than a non-existing service, the implementation should not use InitResponse() to set a response code. However, it is possible to add headers, for example a DESCRIPTION header before the response is sent by invoking PostResponse().

Therefore the minimal implementation of the method only contains a call to PostResponse(). On completion of the DISCONNECT operation, OnDisconnected() is called with an ObexResult parameter indicating success.

Parameters:
headers Header list which optionally contains the headers of the DISCONNECT request sent by the remote client.

Reimplemented in ObexFtpDataServer.

virtual void ObexDataServer::OnGetComplete (  ObexResult  result  )  [inline, protected, virtual]
 

Indicates completion of a GET operation.

Parameters:
result ObexResult which evaluates to 'TRUE' when the operation was completed successfully, 'FALSE' when the operation terminated abnormally. Check the error code then to obtain more detailed information.

Reimplemented in ObexFtpDataServer.

virtual void ObexDataServer::OnGetHeaders (  const ObexHeaderList &  headers  )  [inline, protected, virtual]
 

Indicates reception of OBEX headers within a GET operation.

This method delivers headers received within an ongoing GET operation. Please note that PostResponse() must be called in order to continue the ongoing operation.

Reimplemented in ObexFtpDataServer.

virtual void ObexDataServer::OnGetIncoming (   )  [inline, protected, virtual]
 

Indicates the beginning of an incoming GET operation.

Reimplemented in ObexFtpDataServer.

virtual void ObexDataServer::OnPutComplete (  ObexResult  result  )  [inline, protected, virtual]
 

Indicates completion of a PUT operation.

Parameters:
result ObexResult which evaluates to 'TRUE' when the operation was completed successfully, 'FALSE' when the operation terminated abnormally. Check the error code then to obtain more detailed information.

Reimplemented in ObexFtpDataServer.

virtual void ObexDataServer::OnPutHeaders (  const ObexHeaderList &  headers  )  [inline, protected, virtual]
 

Indicates reception of OBEX headers within a PUT operation.

This method delivers headers received within an ongoing PUT operation. Please note that PostResponse() must be called in order to continue the ongoing operation.

Reimplemented in ObexFtpDataServer.

virtual void ObexDataServer::OnPutIncoming (   )  [inline, protected, virtual]

void ObexDataServer::OnSetPath (  const ObexHeaderList &  headers,
UINT8  flags
)  [protected, virtual]
 

Indicates an incoming SETPATH operation.

Parameters:
headers Header list which normally contains a NAME header which specifies the directory to change into.
flags SETPATH flags which specify the intended behaviour of the SETPATH operation.
If ObexObject::SetpBackup is set, the current directory should be changed to the parent directory, like "cd .." would do under UNIX.

If ObexObject::SetpDontCreate is set and the directory specified by the NAME header does not exist, it must not be created.

See also:
ObexObject::SetPathFlags

Reimplemented in ObexFtpDataServer.

ObexResult ObexDataServer::PostResponse (   ) 
 

Schedules response for transmission.

When a request is currently being handled, the response is send out immediately. Otherwise, especially while data is being transferred after AcceptData() or ProvideData() have been called, the response is queued and sent out at the next opportunity to do so.

Returns:
ObexResult which evaluates to 'TRUE' when the current response was scheduled for sending, 'FALSE' otherwise.

ObexResult ObexDataServer::ProvideData (  BinData *  data_src_ptr  ) 
 

Provides outbound BODY data within a GET operation.

May be called only after OnDataRequested() was signalled to the server. Calling ProvideData() implies posting a SUCCESS response which means that headers describing the object to be sent should be added before AcceptData() is called. Therefore it also does not make sense to call PostResponse() synchronously before or after AcceptData().

Returns:
ObexResult which evaluates to 'TRUE' when the data transfer procedure was successfully initiated, 'FALSE' otherwise.

void ObexDataServer::SetGetFragSize (  UINT  frag_size  ) 
 

Sets the fragment or 'chunk' size for GET operations.

This method specifies the size of the buffer used transfer data within a GET operation. Very small sizes may affect performance due to an unnecessary high number of APOXI messages being used while very large sizes may affect system responsiveness.

The buffer size for PUT operations is determined by the transport implementation and therefore can't be changed by this API.

Parameters:
frag_size Buffer size in octets, must be at least MinGetFragSize.
